          Create a signal with the same xValues as this signal, but yValue = xValue*slope+offset That is, a line through ( 0, offset ) with the given slope

          returns a new Signal with the same xValues as this signal, but digitized if y[i]highThreshold, yr[i]=1 if lowThreshold

 double[] findCrossesDownX(double threshold)
          find the x-values at which the y-values cross the given threshold while going down find the times and indices where the yvals vector crosses the threshold, ( (1-fractions(i))*yvals(i) + fractions(i) yvals(i+1) == threshold ) the returned x-values are obtained by linear interpolation
 double[] findCrossesUpX(double threshold)
          find the x-values at which the y-values cross the given threshold while going up find the times and indices where the yvals vector crosses the threshold, ( (1-fractions(i))*yvals(i) + fractions(i) yvals(i+1) == threshold ) the returned x-values are obtained by linear interpolation

 Signal swapXY()
          create a new signal with swapped x and y values compared to this signal the new Signal's x-values are this signal's y-values the new Signal's y-values are this signal's x-values

       throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

Parameters:

y -
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if x.length != y.length, except if y.length()==0 y.length()==0 is allowed to enable use of not-loaded signals (TODO: check)

getValueAt

public double getValueAt(double xValue)
                  throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
get the yValue that corresponds to the (first occurrence) of the given xValue.

Returns:
the yValue that corresponds to the given xValue. Linear interpolation is used
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if xValue is outside the range of this signal's xValues

resampleGeneral

public Signal resampleGeneral(double[] xValues)
resample this signal at different xValues. Values outside the range are extended with the last stored point Lousy implementation for now

Parameters:
xValues -
Returns:
a new signal with values at the requested xValues

resample

public Signal resample(double[] xValues)
resample this signal at different xValues. Values outside the range are extended with the last stored point. This method assumes strictly increasing xValues TODO: still slow --- create a non-cloning version of getXValues ???

Parameters:
xValues -
Returns:
a new signal with values at the requested xValues

getSubSignal

public Signal getSubSignal(double T1,
                           double T2)
create a subsignal from this signal, over the x-interval [ T1 .. T2 ] All x-values xi in the interval [ T1 .. T2 ] are maintained. No additional values are added in ] T1 .. T2 [ if there is no xi==T1, (T1, y1) is added, where y1 is the interpolated value [ using getValueAt() ] if there is no xi==T2, (T2, y2) is added, where y2 is the interpolated value [ using getValueAt() ] It is assumed that this.xValues is strictly increasing

Parameters:
T1 -
T2 -

getInvertedSignal

public Signal getInvertedSignal()
Returns:
a new Signal x,-y

getAbsoluteValue

public Signal getAbsoluteValue()
Returns:
a new Signal x,abs(y)

integrate

public double integrate()
integrate this signal int( y(t), t=t_0..t_N ) a trapezoidal rule is used: int ~= sum[ n=0..N-1 , (y(n)+y(n-1))/2 * ( t(n+1)-t(n) ) ]

Returns:
the integrated value

integrate

public double integrate(double T1,
                        double T2)
integrate this signal int( y(t), t=T0..T1 ) a trapezoidal rule is used: result ~= sum[ n=0..N-1 , (y(n)+y(n-1))/2 * ( t(n+1)-t(n) ) ]

Returns:
the integrated value

shiftX

public Signal shiftX(double deltaX)
create a new Signal with xnew[i] = xold[i]+deltaX positive deltaX hence means a shift to the right

shiftToOriginX

public Signal shiftToOriginX()
create a new Signal where the xValues are shifted so that x[0]=0 result = this.shiftX( -x[0] )

stretchX

public Signal stretchX(double factor)
create a new Signal with xnew[i] = xold[i]*factor

Parameters:
factor -
Returns:

swapXY

public Signal swapXY()
create a new signal with swapped x and y values compared to this signal the new Signal's x-values are this signal's y-values the new Signal's y-values are this signal's x-values

Returns:

findCrossesX

public double[] findCrossesX(double threshold)
find the x-values at which the y-values cross the given threshold find the times and indices where the yvals vector crosses the threshold, ( (1-fractions(i))*yvals(i) + fractions(i) yvals(i+1) == threshold ) the returned x-values are obtained by linear interpolation

findCrossesUpX

public double[] findCrossesUpX(double threshold)
find the x-values at which the y-values cross the given threshold while going up find the times and indices where the yvals vector crosses the threshold, ( (1-fractions(i))*yvals(i) + fractions(i) yvals(i+1) == threshold ) the returned x-values are obtained by linear interpolation

findCrossesDownX

public double[] findCrossesDownX(double threshold)
find the x-values at which the y-values cross the given threshold while going down find the times and indices where the yvals vector crosses the threshold, ( (1-fractions(i))*yvals(i) + fractions(i) yvals(i+1) == threshold ) the returned x-values are obtained by linear interpolation

lowerAndHigherThan

public boolean lowerAndHigherThan(double thresholdLow,
                                  double thresholdHigh)
returns true if a signal reaches both values above thresholdHigh and below thresholdLow. The method can be used to find the signals that make logical transitions.

Parameters:
thresholdLow -
thresholdHigh -
Returns:

digitize

public Signal digitize(double lowThreshold,
                       double highThreshold,
                       double resultInbetween)
returns a new Signal with the same xValues as this signal, but digitized if y[i]highThreshold, yr[i]=1 if lowThreshold
Parameters:
lowThreshold -
highThreshold -
resultInbetween - the value that is assigned to indices where lowThresholdReturns:

reverse

public Signal reverse()
return a new Signal in which the order of the xValues is reversed. e.g. (x1 y1) (x2 y2) (x3 y3) becomes (x3 y3) (x2 y2) (x3 y3)

Returns:
